name: Vietnamese Lemongrass Roast Chicken (Gà Nướng)
description: Here is a Vietnamese chicken recipe that you can either grill for a charred smoky flavor on the weekend or quickly roast in the oven for a weeknight dinner. Infused with the amazing flavor of five-spice and lemongrass, this simple chicken recipe goes well with steamed rice with a side of vegetables or in a classic Vietnamese bánh mì sandwich.
keywords: chicken, roast chicken, grilled chicken, roast chicken recipe, asian roast chicken recipe, asian grilled chicken recipe, Bánh Mì Gà, banh mi ga recipe, how to make chicken for banh mi ga, Vietnamese roast chicken recipe, chicken recipe, banh mi ga, chicken sandwich, sweet and savory chicken, oven baked five spice chicken recipe, vietnamese baked five spice chicken recipe, five spice chicken recipe, Vietnamese five spice chicken recipe, five spice chicken, Vietnamese five-spice roast chicken, Vietnamese five-spice baked chicken, Vietnamese five-spice roasted chicken, Vietnamese five-spice grilled chicken, Gà Nướng Ngũ Vị Hương, ga nuong ngu vi huong, ga nuong, five spice chicken with honey, honey five spice chicken, easy Vietnamese chicken recipe, Gà Nướng, asian chicken recipe, asian five spice chicken recipe, what is five spice powder, what is Chinese five spice powder, Vietnamese chicken banh mi ga recipe, easy Asian chicken recipe, easy five spice chicken recipe, Bánh Mì Gà Nướng, vietnamese chicken sandwich, lemongrass, Chinese five spice powder, Vietnamese lemongrass roast chicken, Vietnamese lemongrass roast chicken recipe, cam huong's Chinatown chicken, cam huong chicken, oakland chinatown chicken, cam huong roast chicken, cam huong roast chicken copycat recipe, cam huong copycat recipe, cam huong chicken recipe
recipeIngredient: 4 lbs chicken thighs (about 9 bone-in chicken thighs)
2 tablespoons minced fresh garlic (about 4 large cloves)
recipeInstructions: Mix oyster sauce, soy sauce, fish sauce, honey, sugar, cooking wine, five-spice powder, black pepper, garlic, and lemongrass in a bowl. Adjust the quantities to taste. This sauce is sweet and savory, but if you find it too sweet, reduce the amount of sugar to suit your preference.

For bone-in chicken, use scissors or a knife to cut the meat around the bone so that it lays flat for faster and even cooking. Marinate the chicken with the mixture for at least one hour or overnight in the fridge for best results.

Line a roasting pan with foil to reduce cleanup. Place a wire rack on top if you have one. If not, you can place the chicken directly on the foil-lined tray. Arrange the chicken, skin-side down if applicable. For boneless chicken thighs, cook at 400°F for 15 minutes, then flip and cook for another 15 minutes. For bone-in chicken thighs, cook for 20 minutes per side.

To get beautiful, crispy, and slightly charred skin, transfer the tray to the highest rack in the oven. Baste with pan drippings on both sides. Switch the oven setting to broil at 550°F (the highest broil setting) and broil for 1-2 minutes per side until you get your desired finish.
